awd_titl_txt: Improved Dating of Archaeological Materials with Coordinated Stable Isotope Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Determining the ages of archaeological sites is essential for assessing the timing and rates of human behavioral and biological evolution, and for synchronizing archaeological, fossil, and paleoenvironmental records across sites.  Current techniques for dating archaeological sites do not fully meet these needs, especially at sites older than 50 thousand years.  This project will develop 1) a new approach for determining ages and apply it to several important Middle Stone Age archaeological sites, and 2) a technique that uses archaeological materials to provide paleoenvironmental reconstructions for these sites during human occupation. The project will enhance the infrastructure for archaeological research across existing laboratories, allowing more informative study of museum collections that may contain unique or irreplaceable artifacts. The investigators will promote teaching, training and learning by engaging undergraduate science majors, technicians conducting the research, and a female PhD candidate who is a first-generation college attendee, in novel analytical protocols and approaches to data interpretation. The project will also support international collaborations, research, and science outreach, at sites that include a UNESCO-World Heritage Center.

The archaeological record of the Middle Stone Age (300 thousand to 30 thousand years ago) is critical for understanding the biological and behavioral origins of our species, Homo sapiens. It encompasses the earliest known fossils of anatomically modern humans, provides abundant evidence for accelerated behavioral innovation relative to prior intervals, and coincides with the expansion of modern humans out of Africa.  In this project, stable isotope and uranium-thorium dating of ostrich eggshells will be applied at sites in eastern and southern Africa that record the Middle Stone Age. The project will develop and apply uranium-thorium dating of ostrich eggshells, a common material in Old World archaeological sequences, and will employ stable isotopes of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen in ostrich eggshell to provide improved local records of past mean annual precipitation, vegetation, and aridity.  In sum, these dual methods will enhance archaeologists' ability to extract chronological and paleoenvironmental information from many Old World archaeological sequences and will advance understanding of the timing, tempo, and driving factors of Middle Stone Age behavioral and cultural innovations.

por.por_cntn:
Archaeology relies on accurate, precise dating. Such dating is needed to assess the timing and tempo of human behavioral and biological evolution, correlate archaeological sequences, establish relations between paleoenvironmental, archaeological and fossil records, and relate the physical archaeological record to emerging insights from DNA studies.  Research supported by this award developed and applied a promising new approach to uranium-thorium (U-Th) dating of ostrich eggshells, a common material in African archaeological sequences of the Middle Stone Age (MSA; c. 300,000 to 30,000 years ago).

The MSA begins about the same time that fossil evidence indicates the emergence of our own species. Although rich records of accelerating behavioral and technological innovation exist at many MSA sites, dating them can be challenging in part because most of the MSA lies beyond the effective range of radiocarbon dating, which is limited to ~50,000 years. Yet, dating is essential to research aimed at understanding what drove MSA innovations, ultimately leading to the spread of our species across the Old World and the contemporaneous demise of other members of the genus Homo such as Neanderthals, Denisovans, and others.

We first tested our new approach to U-Th dating of ostrich eggshells by dating eggshells whose ages were independently known from radiocarbon dating and found good agreement between the two types of ages. We next showed that U-Th ages of eggshells provided self-consistent ages for a South African shell midden formed starting about 120,000 years ago, demonstrating the utility of the U-Th-on-eggshell technique well beyond the limit of radiocarbon dating and providing a firm age for early human use of marine food resources.

We also conducted coordinated studies of nitrogen, carbon, and oxygen isotopes in ostrich eggshell, which provide informative records of local mean annual precipitation, vegetation, and aridity, respectively, information which helps to define the environmental context of MSA sites.

We showed that eggshell stable isotopic records from two archaeological sequences in Tanzania and Kenya indicate that relatively stable paleoenvironmental conditions persisted at the two sites during the Middle to Later Stone Age transitions recorded there. These results suggest that the observed developments in material culture were not driven by local environmental change.

Ostrich eggshells also occur in the Near East and Asia and eggshells of other ratites (large, flightless birds) with similar structure and composition are present in Australia and elsewhere.  Our results therefore help to inform dating and paleoenvironmental studies throughout much of the Old World.

The award provided financial support and training for a female, first-generation college attendee that included engaging in novel dating and stable isotope research, learning state-of-the-art analytical techniques, and interacting with accomplished colleagues from multiple domestic and international institutions.
